title: Pregnant mum 'could tell from doctor's face' she'd lost baby at 39 weeks
text:

A pregnant mum says she could tell from her doctor's face that she'd lost her baby at 39 weeks.

Jo Emmott-Myles’ waters broke just days before her due date - and after a perfect pregnancy, the expectant mum thought she would be welcoming a healthy baby into the world.

But when doctors tried to find a heartbeat, Jo said she knew from their faces it was not good news and she sadly gave birth to daughter Alice, who was stillborn.

Throughout her pregnancy, Jo had been considered “low risk” as she had already had a son, Charlie, now 13.

But when her waters broke 39 weeks into her pregnancy, they were slightly discoloured, rather than clear, and she was advised to attend King’s Mill Hospital, in Sutton-in-Ashfield, for assessment.

Jo, 35, said: “They told me to go in and they took me into the triage room as usual. They tried to find the heartbeat and couldn’t, that’s when they got the portable scanning machine in.

“The doctor didn’t even have to say anything, I could tell from his face.”

(Image: Timelessvisualz)

Jo was then induced before giving birth on February 15, 2015 to little Alice.

The heartbroken mum said: “I had some complications in the actual birth. I got an infection, Alice had shoulder dystocia so the birth was not only emotionally traumatic, but it was physically traumatic, and the worst thing was it was all quiet. Very weird.”

A post-mortem examination found that Alice passed away due to a problem with the placenta, reports Nottinghamshire Live.

Jo explained: “When my placenta had formed, there were little parts of it that hadn’t formed fully. Blood clots had occurred in those little parts.

“The baby requires more oxygen from the placenta [during labour] but because of this, not enough oxygen was being passed along and that’s why she passed away.”

Jo, of Mansfield, has since experienced three further losses. She lost her daughter Olivia at 15 weeks into pregnancy and experienced two miscarriages – one at eight weeks into pregnancy and another at 12 weeks.

All of her losses were in 2015 and 2016.

(Image: Timelessvisualz)

Then in 2017, Jo welcomed her “rainbow baby” James, who is now two years old.

And Jo is expecting another baby, which is due on February 15 next year.

Jo has shared her story as part of Baby Loss Awareness Week, which runs from Wednesday, October 9, to Tuesday, October 15.

Jo, who works as academy lead support at National Grid, believes it is vital that more is done to break the “taboo” of discussing baby loss.

She said: “When I lost Alice I never realised you could lose a baby that close to your due date.

“When you enter that world of baby loss it’s like someone has pulled away a curtain and you just discover it. It shouldn’t be like that. People need to be aware. It’s not about scaring people when they are pregnant, people need to be aware that it happens.

“If we’re talking about mental health wellbeing a lot, I think this is very much part of it.”

Baby loss awareness week runs from October 9 - 15 to raise awareness about pregnancy and baby death in the UK. Throughout the week bereaved parents unite and share their experiences.

You can join in Baby Loss Awareness Week's Wave of Light by lighting a candle at 7pm on October 15 and sharing it on social media with #waveoflight and #BLAW2019.
description: Jo Emmott-Myles’ waters broke just days before her due date - and after a perfect pregnancy, the expectant mum thought she would be welcoming a healthy baby
